qas.question: what was the name of Blake Baxter's 1986 hit recording?

answers.text: "When we Used to Play / Work your Body"

qas.question: what was the name of Blake Baxter's 1987 hit recording?
what group released "Big Fun" and "Good Life" in 1988?
what was the 1989 hit theme released by KMS?

plausible_answers.text: "When we Used to Play / Work your Body"

qas.question: What was the name of Steve Hurley's 1986 hit recording?
What was the name of Blake Hurley's 1987 hit recording?
What group released "Big Fun" and "Good Life" in 1987?
What was the 1988 hit theme released by KMS?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Kevin Saunderson<b5_0/><a0_0/>'s company KMS Records contributed many releases that were as much house music as they were techno. These tracks were well received in Chicago and played on Chicago radio and in clubs.[citation needed] Blake Baxter's 1986 recording, <a1_0><b6_0>"When we Used to Play / Work your Body"<b6_0/><a1_0/>, 1987's <a2_0><b7_0>"Bounce Your Body to the Box"<b7_0/><a2_0/> and "Force Field", "The Sound / How to Play our Music" and "the Groove that Won't Stop" and a remix of "Grooving Without a Doubt". In 1988, as house music became more popular among general audiences, Kevin Saunderson's group <a3_0><b8_0>Inner City<b8_0/><a3_0/> with Paris Gray released the 1988 hits "Big Fun" and "Good Life", which eventually were picked up by Virgin Records. Each EP / 12 inch single sported remixes by Mike "Hitman" Wilson and Steve "Silk" Hurley of Chicago and Derrick "Mayday" May and Juan Atkins of Detroit. In 1989, KMS had another hit release of <a4_0>"<b9_0>Rock to the Beat<b9_0/>"<a4_0/> which was a theme in Chicago dance clubs.[citation needed]
